Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to the UH-1Y and AH-1Z aircraft and related systems. The overall goals associated with these modifications are to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates, eliminate safety hazards, improve survivability, fulfill operational requirements, remedy obsolescence, and sustain/improve mission capability in support of the Marine Air Ground Task Force and joint operations worldwide.

The H-1 Series modifications within this line item are grouped into three focus areas: H-1 Avionics Improvements (OSIP 015-12), H-1 Sensors and Weapons Improvements (OSIP 016-12), and H-1 Air Vehicle Improvements (OSIP 013-14). 

The mission of the UH-1Y utility helicopter is to provide command and control and combat assault support under day/night and adverse weather conditions and special operations support: supporting arms coordination and aeromedical evacuation. The H-1 aircraft provide local civilian and military search and rescue support, as well as augmenting Department of Homeland Security resources. The AH-1Z are tandem-seat, two-place attack helicopters.  The mission of the AH-1Z attack helicopter is to provide rotary wing close air support, anti-armor, armed escort, armed/visual reconnaissance, anti-helicopter and point air defense and fire support coordination during day/night conditions. The current armament of the AH-1Z includes the Sidewinder and Hellfire missile systems, Joint Air to Ground Missile (JAGM), a chin-mounted 20mm turret gun, and a wide variety of forward-firing and gravity-released external stores. Improvements also include software updates and integration test assets to support engineering modifications and changes.

The aircraft inventory objective for the UH-1Y for FY 2021 is projected to be 145 aircraft.
The aircraft inventory objective for the AH-1Z for FY 2021 is projected to be 161 aircraft.

Justification.val:
The FY 2020 enacted includes congressional rescissions of $9.25 million to FY 2019 funding. However, these rescissions are not reflected on the P-40 and associated detail P-3a.

FY 2021 budget request modifies the UH-1Y and AH-1Z aircraft and related Avionics, Sensors and Weapons, and Air Vehicle systems to address critical capability gaps. 

Funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 supports: Avionics efforts-DI-Full Motion Video Phase 2.0, Wireless Internal Communication System, Ethernet Backbone, ARC-210 Gen 6 RT-2036 Mobile User Objective System, Mission Computer Retrofit, Crash Survivable Recorder; Sensor and Weapons efforts-APR-39D(V)2 and Target Sight System Block Upgrade; Air Vehicle efforts-Tail Rotor Drive Shaft, Swashplate Improvements, Environmental Control System, Floorboards Upgrade Kits, Drive Plate Improvements, Rotor Brake System, Main Rotor Gear Box Tiltball, Inverters, and DC Generator.

Name.@footnote: 3.2) Data-Increase in FY 2021 is due to procurement of digital map licensing for Ethernet Backbone.

3.5) ILS-Increase in FY 2021 provides logistic efforts supporting production activities migrating over to fleet modifications and depot level installs for DI-FMV Phase 2.0, Wireless Inter-Communication System (WICS), Ethernet Backbone, Mission Computers (MC), Enhanced Navigation, and ARC-210.

3.6) Other Support-Increase in FY 2021 provides programmatic, engineering, and technical support for production activities migrating over to fleet modifications and depot level installs for DI-FMV Phase 2.0, Wireless Inter-Communication (WICS),  Ethernet Backbone, Mission Computer (MC), Enhanced Navigation, and ARC-210.

Name.@footnote: 1.1.1) DI-Full Motion Video (FMV) Phase 1.0-DI Full Motion Video (FMV) supports Urgent Universal Needs Statement (UUNS) CDTS# 11061UA.  The separation of DI-FMV was made to reflect a phase 1 which includes a 2 tail-mounted antennas and a carry-on ANW2 waveform capability, which provides an interim capability to meet the UUNS.

Installation 1 of 4: DI-Full Motion Video (FMV) Phase 1.0--The quantiy being installed doesn't align with the current A-II due to the intermediate capability Urgent Needs Statement (UNS) originally being funded for 110 H-1 Aircraft. In the initial deployment technical issues better solved in Phase 2.0 drove a reprioritization to put emphasis on DI-Full Motion video Phase 2.0, reducing the UNS requirement from 110 to 71.

A follow-on Program Objective Memorandum (POM) issue sheet will cover requirement for remaining fleet aircraft.

Title.val: ARC-210 Gen 6 RT-2036 Mobile User Objective System (MUOUS) (UH-1Y)

Name.val: 1.1.8) ARC-210 Gen 6 RT-2036 Mobile User Objective System (MUOUS) (UH-1Y) - Organic

Name.@footnote: 1.2.1) Installation Kits N/R-FY 2021 Installation Kits N/R is due to modifications for Ethernet Backbone, DI-FMV Phase 2.0 and Mission Computer engineering.
2.1.2) DI-Full Motion Video (FMV) Phase 2.0-Increase in FY 2021 is due to the cancelation of Phase 1.0 and initial fielding of Phase 2.0 along with escalation cost.

2.1.4) Ethernet Backbone-Cost element added to address Ethernet Backbone which absorbed Aircraft Network Switch (ANS) and Advanced Data Transfer System (ADTS) represented on previous budget submittals.  Ethernet Backbone also includes a Router, a Guard, associated cabling, and A-kit. FY 2021 increase is due to expanded capability requirements.  Ethernet Backbone enables the integration of capabilities that have dependencies on increased bandwidth and throughput for high volume data technologies.  The backbone will support Multi-level security for the segregation of operational data vs maintenance and support data.  The system will support a comprehensive solution for data aggregation and distribution via a solution that is similar to a client server style subscription of data for usage.

2.1.6) Mission Computer (MC) Retrofit-The Army procured 56 Mission Computers (MC) in FY 2019 which afforded us the opportunity to take economic ordering quantity.  At this time we are not aware of the Army's need to procure more and thus remaining at the projected cost with inflation throughout the FYDP.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates changes to H-1 avionics systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready based aircraft and ready- for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations. Systems modified and improved on H-1 aircraft will leverage common architectures and utilize existing technology to the maximum extent practicable to minimize development and procurement costs and to reduce the time to field the modifications.

Specific systems associated with this OSIP are: Mission Computer, Mission Computer Harness for improved video, Digital Map, Flight Control Computer, Wiring Integration Remote Terminals, flight data recorders, maintenance data recorders, video recorders, Digital Video Recorders (DVR), data loaders, air data systems, Multi-Function Displays (MFD), Dual Function Displays (DFD), interoperable video and digital data links (Tactical Video Data Links and Full Motion Video (FMV), Variable Message Format (VMF), Ethernet Backbone capability includes: Router, a Guard, associated cabling, Advanced Data Transfer System (ADTS), and A-kit. Communication systems, Mobile User Objective System (MUOS), Wireless Inter-Communications Systems (WICS), Identification Friend or Foe system Aircraft Dependent Surveillance Broadcast (ADS-B), Selective Availability Anti-Spoofing Module (SAASM), Enhanced Navigation includes: Enhanced Global Positioning System Inertial (EGI) modernization to include an enhanced GPS system, anti-jam antenna and radar altimeter, and Joint Battlefield Command - Platform (JBC-P). 

Safety system modifications are required for collision avoidance systems, Degraded Visual Environment, Ground Proximity Warning System, Terrain Awareness Warning System, Crash Survivable Flight Incident Recorder, Improved Vehicle Health and Monitoring System (IMD HUMS) along with Military Flight Operations Quality Assurance.
 
System Configuration Set (SCS) updates are required for avionics component upgrades and interface modifications to ensure integration of platform weapons and sensors. Other focus areas will include Weapon Repairable Assembly modifications to improve avionics and weapons system reliability, maintainability, accuracy and interoperability.

Name.@footnote: 3.5) ILS-Increase in FY 2021 provides logistic efforts supporting production activities migrating over to fleet modifications and depot level installs for APR-39D(V)2 and Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade.

3.6) Other Support-Increase in FY 2021 provides programmatic, engineering, and technical support for production activities migrating over to fleet modifications and depot level installs for APR-39(D)V-2 and Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: APR-39D(V)2  (UH-1Y/AH-1Z)

Name.@footnote: 1.1.1) APR-39D(V)2-Quantities updated to include both T/M/S (UH-1Y and AH-1Z). A-Kit quantities increased to match B-Kit procurements for both platforms. The UH-1Y/AH-1Z is currently equipped with the legacy APR-39 system. Adjustment allows the UH-1Y/AH-1Z flexibility to deploy aircraft with a common digital processor type that will enhance situational awareness, enhance effectiveness and suitability in complex, hostile environments in support of Marine Expeditionary Operations.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Field Mod Team:: Installation Name: APR-39D(V)2  (UH-1Y/AH-1Z)

Name.@footnote: 2.1.1) Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade-The USMC H-1 Operating Forces Capabilities Planning Document identifies the need for an electro-optical system capable of automatically detecting laser designator energy for purposes of target handoff operations. The Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade includes the TSS Laser Spot Tracker, Turret Electronic Unit, and High Definition upgrade to enable the AH-1Z to detect, acquire, and track laser designator energy for more expeditious target handoff and engagement. Procurement of equipment begins in FY 2021. Quantity and price has been refined based on updated cost information.
Name.val: 2.1.1) Target Sight System (TSS) Block Upgrade (AH-1Z) - Organic

Name.@footnote: 2.1.2) APR-39D(V)2-The UH-1Y/AH-1Z is currently equipped with the legacy APR-39B(V)2 system. Increase in FY 2021 with the modification of (9) UH-1Y's will allow the Marine Corps the flexibility to deploy aircraft with a common digital processor type that will enhance situational awareness, effectiveness and suitability in complex, hostile environments in support of Marine Expeditionary Operations. Quantity and price has been refined based on updated cost information. Quantity differs from A-Kit due to equipment procurement being provided by commodity owner.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates changes to H-1 mission systems sensors, Helmet Mounted Sight Displays (HMSD), Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE), and weapon systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), aircrew situational awareness and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations. Systems modified and improved on H-1 aircraft will leverage common avionics architectures to the extent possible to mitigate development, procurement costs and fielding timelines.  The modifications will specifically address enhancing capabilities, readiness and sensor fusion with the entire ASE, HMSD, and weapons suite to improve both battlefield and situational awareness.

This OSIP addresses the U.S. Marine Corps' operational requirement to detect, identify, and destroy target sets with the precision guided munitions during day, night, and adverse weather conditions.  Sensor systems include the Target Sight System (TSS), which currently provides a night/adverse weather Forward-Looking Infrared and laser designation for the H-1 series helicopter.  Improvements to H-1 series helicopters' weapons systems include both air to ground and air to air missiles, rocket systems, 20mm turreted gun system reliability/obsolescence and weapons accuracy improvement efforts.  These weapon systems include all Precision Guided Munitions, (Advanced Precision Kill Weapon System (APKWS), the Hellfire family of missiles, inclusive of the M299 Hellfire launcher and the Joint Air To Ground (JAGM), AIM-9X integration, associated Aviation Armament Equipment (AAE), and the Digital Rocket Launcher (DRL) and associated Airborne Weapon Support Equipment (AWSE).  Helmet Mounted Sight and Display (HMSD) system, improvements to the Optimized Top Owl (OTO), include Night and Day Module Optic Reliability Improvements, helmet to aircraft integration improvements as well as helmet mapping improvements.  HMSD safety initiatives addressed by this OSIP include, but not limited to, spatial disorientation issues caused by Degraded Visual Environments (DVE), human factor improvements to helmet design, integration and optics improvements. For Sensor Improvements, this OSIP will address TSS Block Upgrades/Modifications to add a Laser Spot Tracker (LST) capability to detect, acquire and track laser designator signatures; Infra-Red (IR) laser pointing devices; add a high definition camera/telescope to increase detection, recognition, and identification ranges. This improvement will upgrade existing gimbal processors, optimize program security initiatives, address AC network and data link capabilities as well as improve upon overall HMSD, weapon and sensor fusion to improve weapons accuracy.  The H-1 Upgrades Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE) suite currently consists of the AN/APR-39B(V)2 RWR, AAR-47E (V)2 Missile Warning Systems (MWS) and the AN/ALE-47 Countermeasures Dispensing System (CMDS).  The AN/APR-39B(V)2 currently installed in the AH-1Z and UH-1Y is obsolete and must be replaced by the AN/APR-39D(V)2.  In addition to the radar detection upgrades of the APR-39D(V)2, IR detection and countermeasures upgrades will be implemented with the integration of the Distributed Aperture Infrared Countermeasures (DAIRCM) system, and processor upgrades in the ALE-47 countermeasures dispensing set.  ASE Suite upgrades are inherent to successful Digital Interoperability and Electronic Warfare (EW) initiatives, such as the integration of the Intrepid Tiger (IT II), that will ensure the H-1 platform can effectively meet network ready requirements.  The interoperability with other battle management systems, provides aircrew with improved situational awareness, battlefield awareness and incorporates an EW capability.  


 
DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  FY 2019-20 began JUONS DAIRCM system installation and Developmental and Operational Test (DT/OT) for 2 x H-1 test aircraft. FY 2021 begins initial procurement of the for Target Sight System Block Upgrade systems.

3.6) Other Support-Increase in FY 2021 provides programmatic, engineering, and technical support for production activities migrating over to fleet modifications and depot level installs for Tailboom Clamp and Retainer, Tail Rotor Drive Shaft, Swashplate Improvements, ECS Thermal, Floorboard Upgrades, Drive Plate Improvements, Rotor Brake System, Main Rotor Gearbox Tiltball, Inverters, Engine Throttle, and DC Generator.

Title.val: Structural Improvements and Electrical Power Upgrades (UH-1Y/AH-1Z)

Name.@footnote: 1.1.6) Structural Improvements and Electrical Power Upgrades-This cost element combined Structural and Electrical Improvements and Electrical Power Upgrade from previous budget submittals to a consolidated title. Structural Improvements incorporates structural provisions for the increased external load weight carrying capability and extend combat radius.  The Structural Improvement includes cabin improvement items, two station defense armament system, and fuel cell qualification.  Electrical System Improvement increases the current capability of the H-1 electrical system to meet current and future power demands of the aircraft, to include accessory quill qualification, AC generator qualification, electrical wiring re-run, and new Universal Stores Control Units (USCU).

Name.@footnote: 1.1.8) Drive Plate Improvements-Cost element added to address drive plate readiness degrader.  This effort will add bushings to the yoke interface to allow for removal and replacement of bearings damaged from fretting/galling/corrosion in lieu of replacing the entire drive plate.

Structural Improvements incorporates structural provisions for the increased external load weight carrying capability and extend combat radius.  The Structural Improvement includes cabin improvement items, two station defense armament system, and fuel cell qualification.  Electrical System Improvement increases the current capability of the H-1 electrical system to meet current and future power demands of the aircraft, to include accessory quill qualification, AC generator qualification, electrical wiring re-run, and new Universal Stores Control Units (USCU).

Name.@footnote: 2.1.4) Main Rotor Gear Box (MRGB) Tiltball-Increase in FY 2021 Main Rotor Gear Box (MRGB) Tiltball is due to a delay in the FY 2020 procurement cycle.
Name.val: 2.1.4) Main Rotor Gear Box (MRGB) Tiltball (UH-1Y/AH-1Z) - Organic

Name.@footnote: 2.1.5) Inverters-Increase in FY 2021 for (75) Inverters will have a positive impact on readiness of the UH-1Y Fleet. Existing UH-1Y inverters are currently experiencing high rates of failure (low reliability) which is having a negative effect on the readiness of the UH-1Y Fleet. Reports show these inverters have a Mean Time Between Failure (MTBF) average of 263 hrs. The new Digital Signal Processor (DSP) type inverter calculated MTBF is 3,468 hrs. Replacing current inverters with new DSP-type inverters increases time between replacement by ~3,205 hours per unit.

2.1.6) Engine Throttle Stiffness-Cost element added to address engine throttle stiffness. The current bushing in the collective support assembly is a safety hazard by restricting the movement of the worm gear in the outside ranges of collective motion. This is a modification to upgrade the current bushing support assembly as part of the flight control system.

2.1.9) DC Generator-Cost element added to address the DC generator readiness degrader.  The upgraded generator will provide an increase in Mean Time Before Failure (MTBF) and also provides an increase in DC power available.
2.2.1) Installation Equipment N/R-Increase in FY 2021 is due to modifications for Inverters, DC Generator, and Structural Improvements and Electrical Power Upgrades.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) incorporates a number of modifications to H-1 Air Vehicle systems, specifically attacking the highest readiness degraders to reduce the total cost of ownership while improving ready-based aircraft and ready-for-tasking rates. Improvements to safety of flight, maintenance, obsolescence (Diminishing Manufacturing Sources/Material Shortages), and readiness degrader items will yield a more interoperable and survivable H-1 force to sustain warfighter capability in support of worldwide operations. 

Planned modifications cover airframes (structural and air vehicle systems), propulsion, survivability, reliability and maintainability, fuel systems, electrical power, drives, engines, rotors, flying qualities, flight controls, human factors, systems thermodynamics, and weight and balance. Particular focus is on continuously reducing total ownership costs by increasing component time on the aircraft. During full scale development testing of the H-1 Upgrades aircraft, data evaluation showed that incorporation of redesigned components applicable to the critical load paths will significantly increase the service life of the aircraft and components to meet the life limit of 10,000 flight hours.

Safety programs include mission grip mounts. Reliability and maintainability modification items include the aircraft electrical system, power distribution system, fuel cells interface improvements, canopy frame, bushings, blade fold rack, gearboxes, standpipes, fuselage/cabin/seats, engine mount and tail boom bearings, main and tail rotor components, aircraft battery, hydraulic distribution, weight reduction initiatives, swashplate, integrated mechanical diagnostic system, clearances, drive system, systems heating/cooling, corrosion/water intrusion control, rotor blade and gun turret covers, engine cowlings, and airframe structural robustness including access panels, and Throttle improvements.  Dynamic Component Reliability includes improvements/upgrades to the rotor brake system, Main Rotor Gear Box (MRGB), Driveplate, and MRGB tiltball. Survivability modifications include, Improved Defensive Armament System (IDAS) for carrying stores (UH-1Y machine guns, rocket pods, fuel tanks, etc.), and armored flooring. Electrical power modifications include generators and inverters.

Other structural modifications include: swash plate assembly, clamp ring assembly, tail boom assembly, main rotor blades, and canopies. Human factor improvements include Aircrew Restraint System (ARS). Propulsion improvements to tail boom wiring and drives. Thermal cooling improvements include Environmental Control System (ECS).

ImplementationMethodName.val: Support Only Installation

Description.val: The FY 2020 enacted includes congressional rescissions of $9.25 million to FY 2019 funding. However, these rescissions are not reflected on the P-40 and associated detail P-3a.
